Labor Relations Board) regulations

New Urban Program Offers 'Relevant' Major
In response to a cresendo of voices
clamoying for,"relevant, edtication at
Hopkins, a new plan for an Urban Affairs
curriculum has been drawn up by concerned students.
Recent discussions show these proposals "well received by the faculty and
'people from the community," according
to Jim Archibald. Archibald is the President of the Student Association and one
of the movement's proponents.
The plan was formulated following the
establishment of the Johns Hopkins Urban
Affairs Center "in recognition of the
University's responsibility to the needs
of the Baltimore Community." The
administration simultaneously implemented an Urban Affairs course of study
in the Social and Behaviorial Sciences,
supplemented by related courses in
Social Relations, Geography, Environmental Engineering, Economics,History
and Education.

Blueprint for Change
However, as a result of inefficient
planning and the desire on the part of
a group of students led by Archibald,
Sam Katz, Ron Remick, Paul Allen and
Harry Singleton to "keep pace with new
developments in the area," a new blueprint for an Urban Affairs Concentrate
was drafted. The students then met with
prominent people from the Social Relations Department and the Center to discuss the recommendations. Both Archibald and Dean Swanson, who sat in on the
meeting, described the discussion as
fruitful.
The proposals incorporate three basic
recommendations: seminars dealingwith
poverty, health problems, physical planning, crime, and delinquency will be
offered. It is hoped they will supplement

SA Draft Counselling Offers Viable Alternatives
The free draft counselling service of
Levering Hall is designed to make people
aware of the alternatives open to them
under the Selective Service Act.
"We try to help individual young men
to make responsible decisions about their
future," said Leonard Turk a graduate
student and draft counsellor. He noted
that a lot of people "refuse to deal with
their own futures." This has become apparent in the poor attendance which is
generally from the 18 to 19 year age
bracket with few graduate students taking advantage of the service.
Dr. Chester Wickwire, chaplain of the
University, was instrumental in developing the draft counseling program. For
the last two years this service has
operated out of Levering Hall, although
it receives only nominal funding from
the University.

person from all military service and

in the medical corps. Because the holder

armed forces it helps to fill the quota

The Numbers: How Many Were There?
(CPS)--There is something much more
significant about the numbers game being
played with crowd estimates for the November Mobilization activities than is immediately visible. The fact that estimates
have ranged from 170,000 to two million
does not necessary reflect a lack of sophisticated means for counting crowds as
much as it could reflect a conspiracy to
play down the number of people who came
out to protest Nixon's War in Washington.

Double Saxed

Parker: Truth Is Stranger Than Reality
Following the famous gold standard
telegram to the St. Louis convention,
Alton B. Parker continued his self-imposed hibernation until the last week of
the 1904 campaign. By then desperate
measures were clearly called for.
Of course there were wildly optimistic
press releases from various Democratic
committees, but to objective observers
It was clear that the Parker campaign
was moribund. Decisive areas were
falling to President Roosevelt. New
York, the decisive state in all three
Cleveland campaigns, was always considered essential to Parker's hopes. At
the start of the campign New _York was
considered a doubtful state. President
Roosevelt, a political perfectionist who
was far more apprehensive than he had
to be about this campaign, had tried to
bolster the Republican cause in the state
by drafting Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler
to run for Governor. Unfortunately there
were New York Democrats who desired
to see their candidate, and Parker's lack
of vigor in the campaign counted against
him. At the
close of
camthe
paign, publications
were generally
assigning New York to Roosevelt.
This information virtually doomed the
Parker campaign and there was nothing
to compensate for it. William J. Bryan's lukewarm support was clearly not
enough to influence the Western states
for Parker. In the Midwest, the candidate was virtually unknown. Parker's
running mate was from the small state
of West Virginia. He could do no more
than carry his home state, and conceivably he would not do that much.
By the waning days, it was clear that
Parker's policy of near-total silence had
been found wanting and he might find it
expedient to issue a charge concerning
President Roosevelt. He had a vast area
of discretion concerning what sort of
charge to issue. If one allows that Parker
was the candidate of the conservative
Democrats, charged with representing
himself as "safe and sane" in contrast
to President Roosevelt, one might expect
a press release to the effect that Roosevelt was a dangerous radical bent on
undermining the most venerable American institutions. The fact that Parker
moved in the opposite direction, implicity
describing the President as a lackey of
Wall Street, is rich in revelation concerning the initial hopelessness of the
Parker campaign. The tenor of Parker's
statement indicates a decision made by
his headquarters to the effect that Parker
should suddenly sound the toscin of Bryan and LaFollette against the evils of the
trusts. It is quite conceivable that this
was a more popular position than the
strange call for safety and sanity, but in
Parker the call for reform was out of
character. Parker's gold standard telegram was a master stroke, not only because it showed the candidate in a position of command, but because it placed
him in a conservative position entirely
in accordance with his image. Parker
could only seem silly and inconsistent
as suddenly, in the last week of an uphill campaign, he professed to awake to
the dangers of the trusts and their alleged collusion with President Roosevelt.
This much said, the facts of Parker's
last desperate stroke are relatively
dreary. The Justice elaborated on a
suspicion which had covertly permeated
certain Democratic journals,concerning
the effect that the Republican National
Chairman, George Cortelyou, had formerly been Secretary of Commerce and
Labor. Parker considered it unethical
that the man formerly charged with overseeing trusts was now using his knowledge of business in the attempt to raise
money. He did not cite any specific
cases in which Cortelyou had exacted
tribute in return for a promise not to

prosecute any particular trust. He was
concerned that, as he charged,the trusts
were bankrolling the Republican campaign. The tenor of the Parker statement is that anything that could not be
demonstrated, could be suspected.
Roosevelt, who had been spending the
campaign in uncharacteristic silence,
overruled certain of his advisers and
replied. He said that "the silence of
self-respect" had sealed his lips thus
far. The President wrote with his characteristic vigor, a firming the splendid
moral character of Cortelyou and Parker's evident failure to substantiate himself. He declared that he was controlled by no one except the people, to whom
he sought to give "a square deal, no
more and no less." The fascinating exchange had thus far consisted of Parker's
unsubstantiated charges, followed by
Roosevelt's ringing affirmation that the

charges were unsubstantiated.
The President, a consummate policician, was never shrewder than in this
reply. He issued it on the Friday evening before the elction, for release in
Saturday morning newspapers. Had he
mulled over the statement for another
day or two, the Democrats could have
charged that the late issuance of the
President's rebuttal gave Parker no time
to respond. As matters stood, Parker
would be expected to forumlate some
response. A renewed failure to substantiate his charges would amount to suicide.
There was in fact material which, if
exposed, might have caused a minor sensation, such as the correspondence between the President and Edward Harriman which later agritated Senator LaFollette. Parker lacked knowledge of
this, and his statement of sur- rebuttal

was poor. He declared, with ringing
accuracy, that Mr. Cortelyou had formerly been Secretary of Commerce and
Labor and was now National Chairman.
"Now, these facts are not challenged by
the President, nor can they be." Without offering much other solid fact, he
dazzlingly charged contributions "by the
great monopolists for the continuance
of old favors." This charge is not inconceivable on its face, but Parker
should have cited some great monopolists, some contributions and some old
favors, if, in fact, he knew about them.
Parker closed by indicating that President Roosevelt's defeat would constitute
a stinging "rebuke" to the trusts.
Thus sorrowfully closed the last gamble of Justice Parker. To use a favorite
phrase of President Roosevelt, his "bolt
was shot." Next week I shall discuss the
tense, exciting Election Night.

By GEORGE KIRSCHBAUM
Sports Editor
In the words of Sports Information Director Jim Sydnor, "Coach
Alex Sotir's football team is one of the most disparaged football teams
ever to play at Hopkins.Surely it is the most disparaged championship
team." In the same conversation last Friday, he went on to add that
"it is ironic that such a team will, in all probability, win its division
title." At that time Hopkins had not yet clinched the MAC Southern
Division Title.
Disparaging comments have come from several areas. The NewsLetter or one was responsible for the regrettable Franklin and Marshall article. Walter Herman, former voluntary sports publicity director and alleged associate of Sydnor's wrote a less than complimentary article for the News—American after the Carnegie-Mellon
loss. Coupled with this regretful negative journalism has been constant
student cynicism and belittlement of the Blue Jay Varsity gridders.
Undoubtedly, those who sneer the most at accomplishment or its
lack on the athletic field are also the ones who do most to hurt the
University's attempts to improve the athletic teams.

Incident in Press Box
An example of this is one student who was making derogatory remarks in the pressbox during the Swarthmore football game. Unbeknowst to this student-critic, Coach Jim Valvano was also there with
a basketball prospect. Here, on the one hand, we have a coach trying
to sell a student on Hopkins, and on the other a student cutting down
the University and its sports teams. Competition for good studentathletes is hard enough without this derogatory attitude.
Derision of Hopkins is not limited to the sports scene. It is but one
segment of a larger, more widespread "negativism." This leads into
the second part of my editorial. In fact, I find nothing more irritating
than a group of self-appointed critics—students, faculty, administrators, coaches or anyone else for that matter--sitting around on
Friday afternoon nit-picking at the failings of the News-Letter.
Such aimless non-constructive criticism is a waste of enery. Valid
criticism, such as of the News-Letter's F & M article, which was an
unfortunate mistake and for which I, as Sports Editor, owe both the
team and Coach Sotir an apology, is welcome.

Loudmouth Critics
Yet the loudmouth student-critics of the News-Letter, Hopkins in
general, the Hopkins' athletics in particular could better serve themselves and the Hopkins community if they would contribute responsibly
to the News-Letter and try to correct what they think are "faults" in
it.
I am not saying criticism itself is bad, but it is valuable only if constructive. Anyone can tear down; building is the difficult part. If you
don't think so, ask Coach Sotir who four years ago practically had to
start from scratch to build a winning team.
The News-Letter is a student newspaper,we aim to offer a responsible avenue of communication and information to the Hopkins community. Where we feel there is a wrong such as the University's admissions policy to athletic events, it is our editorial obligation and
duty to expose it. The Sports pages are in intregral part of these aims.
In late January, the News-Letter plans to go twice-weekly which
means we'll need more sportswriters and reporters to give the University responsible coverage it deserves.
I ask you to join the News-Letter team. To borrow Jim Sydnor's
word, we are disparaged too.

Johns Hopkins' football team continued to look
like a small college gridiron powerhouse with a
determined effort against Dickinson College at
Carlisle last Saturday. The Jays won 28-14 in
a contest that was more one-sided than the score
indicates.

ranked 13 in the nation in college football defense.
They had allowed an average of only 177 yards
gained against them while posting a 4-3 record.

game on Nov. 8. The opening series of downs
against Dickinson looked like Swarthmore's fateful third quarter re-lived. Charlie Coker returned the opening kickoff 25 yards to Hopkins 35.

32 yards, and fired to Steve Latson for nine
more. Steve Hata hit the right side of the line
for three tough yards and Dan Augustine bulled
the ball across the goal line five plays later.

Coker took the punt on Hopkins 31. Augustine
went over left tackle for ten yards and on the
following play, sophomore running back Joe Ciesloi,vski took the second handoff on a double reverse and raced with it to the Dickinson endzone. The TD was called back and 15 yards were
assessed for a holding penalty against Hopkins.
The Jays gave the ball up on downs and with third
and two yards to go on Hopkins 40 yard line, Dickinson's speedy halfback John West spurted past
the Hopkins secondary for Dickinson's first score.
The rest of the first quarter was spent inside
the Hopkins 20 yard line. Before the half, Dickinson had seven opportunities to score from good
field position. A great pass rush produced by
Doug Hain, Paul Weiss and Mark Curtis together
with the blanket coverage by the proud, Szabocoached secondary stopped the Dickinson advance
cold. The score at the half was Hopkins eight,
Dickinson seven.

Jays Owned Half
The second half belonged to Hopkins. Again the
defense stopped seven drives while the offense
came alive with solid blocking and smart running.
Hopkins scored on their second series of downs

In the second half.
Steve Utz led the charge with a 65 yard jaunt
around right end. Workhorse Augustine punched
for 12 more yards and Hata pushed it across.
A game Dickinson team tied the score on the
next series but the tie was short lived.
Coker returned the kickoff 40 yards to the Dickinson 47. Augustine bolted left end, cracked the
middle, cracked the middle, cracked the middle,
cracked the middle.... and Hopkins was ahead to
stay.

Jays Made Ball Move
The Jays kept the ball on the ground for the
rest of the game and made it move. The Hopkins
offense scored again to open the fourth quarter.
Second down and ten on the Hopkins 30, Steve
Utz broke around left end for 25 yards on the
strength of a block thrown by Steve Hata. Hata
hit the middle for five yards and Utz went over
left tackle for forty yards and the touchdown.
Dickinson attempted a late quarter passing
attack that drove the ball to the Hopkins 38.
Center linebacker Jim McMenamin intercepted a
pass on the Blue Jays own 22 yard line and raced
it back to the Dickinson 36. The Jays punched
the ball to the Dickinson six before the final
whistle.

Utz Ground Leader
Sophomore running back Steve Utz led the rushing attack with 151 yards in 13 carries and one
touchdown, Dan Augustine gained 119 yards in 24
tries and logged two TD's, and Steve Hata covered 90 yards in 15 attempts.
In all, Hopkins recorded 358 net yards against
the 13th toughest college defense in the nation
while the defense allowed only 218 total yards,
both passing and rushing for Dickinson.
It was an impressive performance for a team
that has had trouble finding itself. The win brought
Hopkins at least a piece of its third straight conference crown.

Last Tuesday, the Varsity Soccer team finished a successful 6-2-2 season by tying another

the strength of the Hopkins' defense,playing without the constant checking and hard hitting of John

Steve Weiss again made several incredible saves,
while Rick Tobey, Gavin Youngquist and Rob Parsley made up well for Clisham's loss.

as it had done against Drexel the previous Saturday. In this game, the offense, led by Scott Tyner, had posted two goals, and had achieved only

our six shutouts this year. Frequently, however,
we just weren't able to put together enough shots
on goal to win a few more games and maybe the
conference title."

on goal, though there were a couple good crosses
in front of the net by samper and Tyner, and one

controversial shot by Miller off the goalpost.

that the Jays, led on by the crowd's cher ring, tried
to win it all by keeping the ball in front of Western
Maryland's net. Despite their inability to score
in the closing minutes, the team showed the good
spirit and agressiveness, which have been evident
throughout this past season.

Knauff's remarks at the end of last Tuesday's
game, when he said, "It was a great pleasure for

the team deserves a lot of credit for our fine
season."

Barry, and Gavin Youngquist, truly do deserve
a lot of credit, in addition to the regulars, for
keeping the team going when it was plagued by

of next year's team, which should continue to
be a strong MAC contender.

By MARK REUTTER
After years of debate, it looks like
Hopkins' Allied Health Program will be
approved by the Board of Trustees despite the objections of a still-vocal minority.
"It will be in a matter of a couple
of weeks," said Vice-President and
Provost, William Bevan, in reference

Medical and Hygiene Schools and the
Board of Trustees.
The present proposal was first explored in January, 1967, by a medical
faculty committee. Since then, the plan
has painstakingly gone through discussion and recommendation stages in the
School of Medicine, School of Public
Health and Hygiene and the Faculty of
Arts and Sciences. It will soon be before the policy-making Advisory Boards
of the Medical and Hygiene Schools.
In a faculty memorandum last month
summarizing the Allied Health proposal,
President Lincoln Gordon stated that
"the University should estbalish baccalaureate and master's programs in the
allied health sciences to which students
would normally be recruited at the conclusion of their undergraduate sophomore year, having completed stated prerequisites especially in the scientific
fields."
These transfer students would enter a
"College of Health Sciences" to complete
a combined baccalaureate-master's degree in either three or four years, according
to Gordon's
memo. The

"College" would be located near the East
Baltimore medical institutions, and
would train nurses and non-doctoral
medical personnel.
Implementation of the Allied Health

gathering new financial resources for the

to begin the division.

announced that money allocated to existing programs will not be touched to start

presently running this year $4 million in
the red, cannot afford additional expenditures without more money.

The Rationale
The rationale behind an Allied Health
division at Hopkins was to train medical
technicians who would absorb many of
the functions now performed by doctors.
"Doctors do a lot of things that don't
need to be done by doctors," Bevan explained, "and what we have in mind is a
whole new type of medical personnel who
would take over many of their jobs."
Through this process, Bevan claimed,
the quantity of qualified medical personnel would be increased without greatly
expanding the number of medical schools
in the nation. "Given the present character of medical education, it is impossible to increase the output of doctors
without starting more medical schools

which is extremely costly, and the
government just doesn't seem to have
the money," he asserted.

by the opponents of the Allied Health
plan: why not expand the medical school
to produce more doctors instead of starting something new, how will a non-doctoral program attract highly - qualified

students."

By GEORGE KIRSCHBAUM
Sports Editor
In the words of Sports Information Director Jim Sydnor, "Coach
Alex Sotir's football team is one of the most disparaged football teams
ever to play at Hopkins.Surely it is the most disparaged championship
team." In the same conversation last Friday, he went on to add that
"it is ironic that such a team will, in all probability, win its division
title." At that time Hopkins had not yet clinched the MAC Southern
Division Title.
Disparaging comments have come from several areas. The NewsLetter or one was responsible for the regrettable Franklin and Marshall article. Walter Herman, former voluntary sports publicity director and alleged associate of Sydnor's wrote a less than complimentary article for the News—American after the Carnegie-Mellon
loss. Coupled with this regretful negative journalism has been constant
student cynicism and belittlement of the Blue Jay Varsity gridders.
Undoubtedly, those who sneer the most at accomplishment or its
lack on the athletic field are also the ones who do most to hurt the
University's attempts to improve the athletic teams.

Incident in Press Box
An example of this is one student who was making derogatory remarks in the pressbox during the Swarthmore football game. Unbeknowst to this student-critic, Coach Jim Valvano was also there with
a basketball prospect. Here, on the one hand, we have a coach trying
to sell a student on Hopkins, and on the other a student cutting down
the University and its sports teams. Competition for good studentathletes is hard enough without this derogatory attitude.
Derision of Hopkins is not limited to the sports scene. It is but one
segment of a larger, more widespread "negativism." This leads into
the second part of my editorial. In fact, I find nothing more irritating
than a group of self-appointed critics—students, faculty, administrators, coaches or anyone else for that matter--sitting around on
Friday afternoon nit-picking at the failings of the News-Letter.
Such aimless non-constructive criticism is a waste of enery. Valid
criticism, such as of the News-Letter's F & M article, which was an
unfortunate mistake and for which I, as Sports Editor, owe both the
team and Coach Sotir an apology, is welcome.

Loudmouth Critics
Yet the loudmouth student-critics of the News-Letter, Hopkins in
general, the Hopkins' athletics in particular could better serve themselves and the Hopkins community if they would contribute responsibly
to the News-Letter and try to correct what they think are "faults" in
it.
I am not saying criticism itself is bad, but it is valuable only if constructive. Anyone can tear down; building is the difficult part. If you
don't think so, ask Coach Sotir who four years ago practically had to
start from scratch to build a winning team.
The News-Letter is a student newspaper,we aim to offer a responsible avenue of communication and information to the Hopkins community. Where we feel there is a wrong such as the University's admissions policy to athletic events, it is our editorial obligation and
duty to expose it. The Sports pages are in intregral part of these aims.
In late January, the News-Letter plans to go twice-weekly which
means we'll need more sportswriters and reporters to give the University responsible coverage it deserves.
I ask you to join the News-Letter team. To borrow Jim Sydnor's
word, we are disparaged too.

Allied Health Ratification Expected Soon
By MARK REUTTER
After years of debate, it looks like
Hopkins' Allied Health Program will be
approved by the Board of Trustees despite the objections of a still-vocal minority.
"It will be in a matter of a couple
of weeks," said Vice-President and
Provost, William Bevan, in reference
to the expected ratification of the program by the Advisory Boards of the
Medical and Hygiene Schools and the
Board of Trustees.
The present proposal was first explored in January, 1967, by a medical
faculty committee. Since then, the plan
has painstakingly gone through discussion and recommendation stages in the
School of Medicine, School of Public
Health and Hygiene and the Faculty of
Arts and Sciences. It will soon be before the policy-making Advisory Boards
of the Medical and Hygiene Schools.
In a faculty memorandum last month
summarizing the Allied Health proposal,
President Lincoln Gordon stated that
"the University should estbalish baccalaureate and master's programs in the
allied health sciences to which students
would normally be recruited at the conclusion of their undergraduate sophomore year, having completed stated prerequisites especially in the scientific
fields."
These transfer students would enter a
"College of Health Sciences" to complete
a combined baccalaureate-master's degree in either three or four years, according
to Gordon's
memo. The

"College" would be located near the East
Baltimore medical institutions, and
would train nurses and non-doctoral
medical personnel.
Implementation of the Allied Health
plan, however, will be contingent upon
gathering new financial resources for the
program, stated Dr. Bevan. Fundsfrom
the Federal Government, from the National Institute of Health and from private
sources will be tapped,Bevan remarked,
to begin the division.
If such funds are not available, the institution of the Allied Health College will
be delayed. President Gordon previously
announced that money allocated to existing programs will not be touched to start
the new school and that the University,
presently running this year $4 million in
the red, cannot afford additional expenditures without more money.

The Rationale
The rationale behind an Allied Health
division at Hopkins was to train medical
technicians who would absorb many of
the functions now performed by doctors.
"Doctors do a lot of things that don't
need to be done by doctors," Bevan explained, "and what we have in mind is a
whole new type of medical personnel who
would take over many of their jobs."
Through this process, Bevan claimed,
the quantity of qualified medical personnel would be increased without greatly
expanding the number of medical schools
in the nation. "Given the present character of medical education, it is impossible to increase the output of doctors
without starting more medical schools

which is extremely costly, and the
government just doesn't seem to have
the money," he asserted.
Three major questions have been posed
by the opponents of the Allied Health
plan: why not expand the medical school
to produce more doctors instead of starting something new, how will a non-doctoral program attract highly - qualified
students, what financial drain will the
program place on the University and
could this training function be performed
by existing trade or vocational schools?
"One hears from many medical
experts that we are in a near-crisis situation in the medical profession," maintained Dr. Francis Carlson professor of
biophysics, "and we should train more
doctors instead of starting another baccalaureate program." He stated that
since a shortage of doctors is now affecting the country,Hopkins, which specializes in such training, should expand its
medical school enrollment. "According
to the Association of American Medical
Colleges, there are 22,000 filed applications for med schools and 10,000 are admittee each year. We should begin to tap
these 12,000 students who have already
received a undergraduate degree before
trying to attract a whole new set of
students."
Dr. Donald Kerr of Physics feared
that the quality of academic instruction
would be lowered if Hopkins began training more nurses and medical technicians.
"I don't like taking on a lower grade of
academic people," Kerr remarked. Furthermore, he noted, a new division within the University cannot help but financia-

Future Plans
The Vietnam Moratorium Committe, which organized
the October 15th anti-war demonstrations, but stayed in
the background this past weekend, has returned to the
forefront by announcing plans for December demonstrations.
Sam Brown, a chief spokesman of the committee, announced plans for three days of nationwide protest activities, on December 12, 13, and 24. All of the demonstrations will be local, with no large rallies planned for
the near future.
Activities planned include the leafleting of Christmas shoppers, and public vigils on Christmas eve. Because of the close proximity of the dates to final ecams
and the Christmas holidays, there was little hope of
any large scale campus action.
"Traditionally, Christmas has been a time when people
turn their attention to peace on earth," Brown stated.
"This year...they will also turn their energies to that
task."
"Public vigils and other appropriate activities will be
organized across the country this Christmas Eve,"
Brown added, emphasizing that this in no way implies
an economic boycott.
New Mobilization officials plan to gether in New York
this weekend to plan future activities. No plans for a
mass rally are expected.

Joplin:No Comfort
Janis Joplin was arrested Monday night following a
concert in Tampa, Fla. for allegedly using profanity
on detectives who interrupted her performance while
controlling the crowd.
Joplin was charged with two counts Of profanity in
the incident which began when part of the 3,500 people
attending began swarming toward the stage and standing on chairs to get a closer look.
After the hall manager threatened to close down the
show, police began moving the audience back. At this
point, according to police, Joplin shouted an obscenity
at the officers and directed several other obscene words
at one particular detective.
Joplin was allowed to finish her concert while Sergeant E. D. Williams went to procure a warrant for
her arrest. She was arrested backstage.

Peace and Love
The wife of Senator Philip A. Hart (D., Mich.) was
one of those arrested at a peace demonstration at the
Pentagon last Thursday.
Explaining her first brush with the law, the 47-yearold mother of eight said: "The point was to have
a mass for peace to bring the idea of peace and love of
God into the house of death."
Instead, along with 185 others at the Mass for Peace,
she was arrested and charged with violating a General
Services Administration rule against blocking a corridor.
She pleaded not guilty, and was released after posting
$25 bond. She and the others are to appear in court
January 14.
Mrs. Hart stated that she didn't remember how her
husband felt about the whole thing. She did say that she
would be "enthusiastic" about a repeat Pentagon demonstration.
In addition to her political activities, Mrs. Hart is
a licensed pilot and has her own campaign to get women
into the space program. She is also finishing her college
education, majoring in anthropology at George Washington University,

During the game, as Lyndon pondered his next move,
he remarked, "That's just the trouble, Sam Houston,

"Now take this Vietnam mess: How in the hell can

got some of the finest brains in this country--people

"Then I've got some people like Fulbright and George
Ball, also intelligent men, whose motives I can't rightly
distrust--and telling me we've got to de-escalate or run
the risk of total war. And Sam, I've got to listen to
both sides."
